body: I run DFL on my Linux desktop and can confirm this. The workaround for now is to set the denoise filter to some value like 5.

Yep, I tried denoise values between 1-10 as a workaround which eliminates ~90-95% of the artifacts but not entirely, often leaving rainbow colored box outlines around the overlayed face area.

This is perhaps helpful for @iperov in debugging the exact stage where the glitches are introduced.

this problem occur only in Linux
I cannot investigate and fix it
You made commits to this repo as "fix for linux" before. You include "requirements-colab.txt" in the codebase. Are you terminating support for Colab/Linux?
colab is used for training. I don't merge in colab.

I am speechless.

So you will only fix bugs you encounter in your personal use?

You should not list Linux and Colab versions as 'releases' on the main page if that is the case - they are merely installers / script-wrappers based on the same exact codebase. And if you are not willing to fix bugs that affect these 'releases', they are at best 'unsupported wrappers'.

Have invested weeks learning to use DFL, training models in Colab, only to be told bugs will not be fixed simply because the creator-developer does not use a 'release' the same way users do?

To prevent others from suffering the same pain and disappointment, I sincerely urge you to clearly label the Linux and Colab versions 'unsupported'.

Thanks.

initially DFL created for windows.
Colab and Linux "forks" made by other users.
Colab works fine for extract and training.
Nobody use colab for merging, because it is interactive.
You can use CPU for merging on your linux windows emulator.

and this is open source.
I don't owe anyone anything.

It is not an issue of you owing anyone anything.

It is an issue of you supporting Linux/Colab half-heartedly and your attitude towards ur community of users who spend time to troubleshoot and put together workspaces for your investigation.

You first said "I cannot investigate and fix it", but when pointed out you have made fixes for Linux before, you say "I don't merge in colab".

So you CANNOT investigate or you WON'T?

If bugs start showing up in the Trainer in Linux too, what will you do?

Will you say Linux and therefore "I cannot investigate"?
Or will you investigate just because "I use it too"?

PS. Again I urge you to label Linux / Colab variants 'unsupported' as far as your codebase is concerned. You can let future forks that are actually properly adapted to the various OS/environments claim to be 'releases'.

PPS. I tried using Merge in Parallels on my Mac - Mac user whole reason why I have to use Colab - but it crashed and I never get to be able to select 'CPU'.

I asked on the mrdeepfakes forum if that was expected behavior because I do not have a Nvidia GPU, and was told-off by tutsmybarreh your 'official' guide support forum moderator and had my question closed -- "only Nvidia GPU" he said.

@dmfp As frustruating as this problem is I wouldn't bash the author of this awesome piece of software, though. The only reason it also runs on linux is because it's written in Python. The linux fork of this project is actually just a bunch of bash scripts that replace the Windows *.bat ones. I'm not so good at programming but I like challenges and if @iperov could point me in the right direction (like what libs/requirements is involved in the merger) I could at least have a look at it :)

this is a bug with opencv on linux
idk how to reproduce it on windows

@iperov 
As birdstream rightly pointed out, u graciously open-sourced ur work, and I wud like say a big thank u in this regard. I wasn't expecting u alone to fix all of DFL's bugs, u certainly don't owe anyone anything indeed. I was just taken aback by what I read as u brushing off the problem simply becoz it is a Linux/Colab problem or that u don't use Merge there. Maybe you did not intend it that way.

I had invested weeks on learning and training in DFL; first raised the issue on mrdeepfakes (had a really bad experience with moderator 'tutsmybarreh' claiming it was likely a hardware issue and prematurely closing my questions whilst giving wrong answers), then with @chervonij (who was helpful and pointed to issue being with main repo), and only then did I reach out to you.

I spent time putting together a demo workspace, documenting and providing example outputs with different settings, etc, all so to help u easily replicate and understand the issue.

All that effort, only to be casually dismissed, was what made me really upset -- I did not bother u with a noob qns, but felt treated as if I were.

PS. If you can confirm the Interactive Merger is meant to work even in Windows emulators/virtual machines w/o Nvidia GPUs, I will post an issue and share detailed logs on how the Merger crashed on launch in Parallels on my Mac. Otherwise, the non-interactive Merger on Colab remains my only choice.

@birdstream 
Thanks for offering to try look into the issue. Much, much appreciated.

PS. Understand the Linux/Colab versions are wholly based on the main repo, hence my comments above.
